tag: html body text table tbody tr td h1 strong span
content: TEXT

tag: html body text table tbody tr td h1 strong span
content: The Journal of the Australian Association of Writing Programs

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p strong span
content: Letters to the Editor

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p strong span
content: The April 2002 issue of Text carried an article by

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p strong a span
content: Kevin Brophy

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p strong span
content: on the prose poem. This article attracted several responses. Tom Shapcott's and Moya Costello's are printed below.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p strong em span
content: from Tom Shapcott

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote span
content: Dear Tess and Nigel

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: Thanks for the new issue of TEXT. I was interested to read Bill Manhire's piece and agreed with much it said and especially the concept of opening students to the concept of reaching into the dark. This ties in with the article on the Prose Poem by Kevin Brophy and I would like to offer a 'response' to Kevin's piece.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p strong span
content: THE PROSE POEM IN AUSTRALIA - AND ELSEWHERE

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: In his article

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: The Prose Poem: A Short History, a Brief Reflection and a Dose of the Real Thing

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: Kevin Brophy gives a quick reading of the history of this genre, beginning in France with Baudelaire and finding, it would seem, some sort of fringe habitation in America. Brophy then goes on to relate difficulties he has had in persuading his students to attempt the forrn.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: I believe his 'difficulties' possibly relate to two things. Firstly, from his article he seems not to have taken account of any Australian attempts to develop the form, and secondly, the sense of resistance he notes might be aligned with attempts to persuade students to write poetry at all.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: This latter statement of mine is, perhaps, overstressing the point, but I think many teaches of creative writing have found a certain resistance among students to attempt poetry outside the old 'mainstream' formal structures. This, in my experience, relates back to the general Australian resistance to any forms of modernism in the 20th century and a suspicion of experimentation as a self conscious literary device.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: At the basic level, new students often have great difficulty in even writing about their local environment. Something far off, fantastic (or fantasy-ful) or glamorous is often the instinctive choice. How many futuristic or Gothic or Neanderthal epics have we seen from beginners? To harness writers down to naming specific streets or suburbs is an early but major task. To make the leap beyond habitation and specific perception into the subjective dislocations and leaps of association implicit in the prose poem is a leap indeed.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: Perhaps if we had an anthology of the Prose Poem in Australia the task os teachers might be considerably lightened. And some very exciting possibilities opened up.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: In 1982 when I was writer-in-residence at Deakin University in Geelong their magazine

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: Mattoid

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: published an interview with me on the prose poem. This was reprinted in 1990 in my collection of essays,

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: Biting the Bullet

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: (Simon & Schuster) and in that I gave not only a run-down on the development of the form, from 19th century France to modern English explorations of the genre, most notably in the U.S. (and leaning on Latin American exemplars, which in the 1960s became suddenly available in translation in the States). Kevin Brophy does not mention the great rise of prose poems in the Latin America, nor Europe, but these were pertinent phases. When Mark Strand and Charles Simic published

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: Another Republic

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: in 1976 (Ecco NY) they made a major step in introducing 17 contemporary poets in English translation. Of these, no less than seven were represented with prose poems, several of them entirely in this form: Francis Ponge, Henri Michaux, Zbigniew Herbert, Julio Cortazar, Octavio Paz, Miroslav Holub and Italo Calvino. Most of these names are now well know, even in Australia.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: My interview article explored some of the reasons these took hold in the creative minds of an important segment of American poets. What I did not mention was that American poetry at that stage had already massively broken with old formal traditions, and 'field poetry' offered an even greater sense of flexibility and layout experiment than the prose poem. Nevertheless, it can be said the prose poem did establish its place and there are many more collections of great interest published than is hinted at in Kevin Brophy's (admittedly concise) article.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: The development of the form in Australia was outlined in my piece, and it might be useful to re-print it at the end of this small response. I had been interested - and still am - in the concept of an anthology of prose poems from Australia, though to date I have not managed to interest a publisher. Perhaps it is now time.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: When I edited the UQP verse anthology

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: The Moment Made Marvellous

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: in 1998 I included prose poems by Pamela Brown, Joanne Bums, Gary Catalano and Judith Rodriguez (her

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: Borges at 73

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: also invokes one of the most influential of the influential Latin American experimenters in the form, seen at its most expansive and flexible).

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: Certainly as a technique, the prose poem continues to attract Australian poets and there are a considerable number of book-length collections that have been published here. I could list, for instance, Andrew Taylor's

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: Parabolas

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: (which as I mentioned in my Mattoid interview was the first book of prose poems to be published in this country), two books by Bruce Beaver (

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: Headlands

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: UQP 1986 and

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: As It Was

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: UQP 1979), two by myself (

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: Turning Full Circle

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: New Poetry 1979 and

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: Stump and Grape and Bopple-nut Bullion

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: 1982), several stunning books by Gary Catalano (including

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: Fresh Linen

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: , UQP 1988), Ania Walwicz, Laurie Duggan (including the award-winning

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: The Ash Range

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: , Picador 1987), Rodney Hall's

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: The Most Beautiful World

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: (UQP 1981), all of Philip Hammiell's books from 1976 to 1994, Rudi Krausmann's

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: From Another Shore

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: (Wild & Woolley 1975), Gerard Lee's

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: Manual For a Garden Mechanic

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: (1976), Alison Croggon's

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: Nevigato

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: (Black Pepper 1996), and books by Pamela Brown, Joanne Bums and Anna Couani. And that is only skimming the surface.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: In addition, many Australian poets have published occasional prose poems which are included in their general collections: Chris Wallace-Crabbe, David Malouf and Kevin Hart, on to M.T.C.Cronin, Luke Davies, John Scott, John Kinsella and Michael Sarabin, again to name only a few.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: What these lists do suggest is that as a distinct genre, the prose poem in Australia is alive and well. Probably in better health than the Sestina, the Sonnet or the Haiku.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: The advantage of an anthology, now, would be to suggest to teachers of creative writing in Australia something of the Australian development of the form. And it has taken, I think, specifically Australian resonances. If it could be said to remain essentially lyrical in its preoccupation with language (and even cadence), it is more gently satirical and sometimes even rueful than its American counterparts. It has less anger, more stoicism. Less extravagance, more essential caution. We are, let us remember, a supremely cautious people. The Tampa affair has, most recently, all too clearly illustrated that.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: But the Australian evolution of the prose-poem is no merely pallid thing, a sort of pale reflection of the wan English versions (and, as with recent English art works which set out to shock, the English prose poem has a terrible posing safety-pin-in-the-nostril and stud-in-the-penis determination that merely chafes). It also has something of the Australian laconic wit and defiance, and it can get under the skin of the more conventional verse structures, which bear the ghostly train of the measured cadence still. As Kevin Brophy says, the prose poem is subversive. That is something Australians have always been good at, even if they are outwardly cautious and conformist. If young readers could see something of the range and scope that has evolved over the last generation of our poets, they might be more able to see for themselves how and where the adventure might take them.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote span
content: THE 1982 INTERVIEW WITH MATTOID: ON PROSE POETRY

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: Mattoid:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p em span
content: Could we start, Tom, by discussing the genre of the prose poem? There seems perhaps a contradiction of terms here. Poetry and prose are separate matters, how can you put them together and expect them to be a 'real' form? What do you think a prose poem can do that either a poem or prose can't do?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: Tom Shapcott: Your statement that it seems a contradiction in terms is the point at which the prose poem began. Most true prose poems operate from a sense of contradiction or I'd prefer to say the tension between certain sorts of claims being made upon language. The basic claims are the demands of an innate lyricism and the demands of prose realism. I think the genre as it has evolved in the last 120 or 130 years or so has tried to make use of the intrinsically dramatic conflict involved. To place it in its historical perspective: the first sustained attempts were by Charles Baudelaire - works written as a result of heightened states through drug-taking. It was the urgency of getting something down, I'm sure, that made him write these as prose. He was a superb craftsman, and he discovered that something came through which was different from what would have resulted had he attempted it in a stanzaic form. There are precursors to that sort of discovery: in the English language Walt Whitman used a non-stanzaic loping structure at a time when it was a real innovation; this was based on the dynamics of the Hebraic psalms, which involve a counterbalance in each sentence. But Baudelaire's prose poems opened up further ways - they were celebratory, in other words, lyrical, but they used the language of ordinary conversational discourse. And it was through the conflict between these two forces that something inherently different came out. The French tradition ever since has explored this. In English, such experimentation was much slower. Eliot's early attempts were quasi-translations of the French, and he later abandoned the form. Then, in the 1920s and 1930s, other (mainly American) writers made sporadic experiments...

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: M:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p em span
content: Your summary of the prose poem's origins and relationships raises several interesting points about the form. Just before we pursue those, though, could you bring your survey up to date?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: TS: American, English, even Australian poets had done the odd little exercise. from the 1920s onward. But the form in English came to a new stage of richness from the late 1950s when American poets started using the prose poem in a serious and sustained way. This was through their postwar interest in European and especially Spanish-language poetry and translations. The Spanish-speaking countries had, as it were, spontaneously fallen for the combination of vigour and violence implicit in the structure. In Australia, Chris Wallace-Crabbe was the first poet to tackle it seriously as a form. He was influenced, though, by the French prose poem, which had become a much more elegant and almost 'courtly' study in layers of irony. Through the last decade the Americans have widely explored the possibilities of the clash between the extrovert dynamism and greed and introverted idealism and despair, and the prose poem allowed them to hit the raw nerve of the subconscious - wham - in a way that had only been tentative before - say, in the work of e e cummings...

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: M:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p em span
content: To pursue that question of form and expectations: if the line-breaks in a poem suggest how we should read it, what means does the prose poem have of directing the expectations we bring to it?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: TS: Very often the 'poetic' part of the prose poem is expressed through an appeal to illogic: to states of receptivity which deny what we have come to expect prose to offer - that is, rational discourse, descriptive clarity, even rhetoric in its conventional sense of persuasion, of using language to set certain cogs in motion. The prose poem creates its lyrical frisson by pointing the reader's anticipatory glands in that direction, and then somehow working a change ... Also, the prose poem seems very much a present-tense form. It operates on a sense of immediacy: I am doing this, this is happening to me. And that's immediately conducive to a dream state, because a dream has exactly that things-are-happening-to-me-now feeling. What's implicit is that I am a passive receiver of certain things. Things flow around the "I". This has become characteristic of a lot of prose poetry: an observer is operated on by all sorts of things, some magical, some absolutely mundane. Often the juxtaposition becomes the active force - 'I am sitting in a car there is a blue pram being wheeled past by a lady wearing a pink floral eiderdown...' The naming quality becomes important.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: M:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p em span
content: So although some of your prose poems suggest a narrative, that's not the important thing?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: TS: No. But there's another interesting quality of the prose poem apart from that surreal experience presented with the openness of a passive dream state. This is the implicitly dramatic context of a you-and-me. The poem becomes a dialogue between writer and reader. Many of the more bizarre elements of a lot of prose poems attempt to provoke the reader into participating in what the work offers. Sometimes shock tactics are used. Sometimes coercive tactics.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: M:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p em span
content: I've noticed that in some of your prose poems there's also a dialogue within yourself, or there's an implied interlocutor, and perhaps very occasionally a dramatic impersonation.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: TS: Yes, though that's less characteristic of the form than the use of surrealism. This is a way in which surrealism has become legitimate, opening up possibilities that seem not just jejune.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: M:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p em span
content: Are there other ways, then, in which voices, or points of view, are important in the prose poem?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: TS: I suggest that the best prose poems of the twentieth century have all tended to be groups of poems which build up into sequences. Octavia Paz, in his book-length

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p em span
content: Eagle of Sun

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: (the first major Latin-American essay in the form, by the way), uses the "I" as an ordinary person full of practicalities, involved with ordinary functions, who is also exploring what it is to be a Mexican, and as well having a vision of the old Aztec gods in the present-day world. All these things cohere because of the surrealism and typical Spanish violence of the juxtapositions, the balance between flat prose and highly florid colouration. It only works as a sequence: each small piece builds upon the next and upon the next, like infinite variation.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: M:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p em span
content: So you get both the advantage of lyricism, which you mentioned earlier, and the more extended scope of prose?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: TS: This is where the prose poem can develop as a major form. It's a way of creating a lyrical epic, if you like, without a narrative but with an implied dramatic context, so that all those things we've been talking about, tensions within even the essence of the word, the words as they cling together in a sentence, are expanded and built upon in this larger accretion. The most exciting and successful prose poems of the last twenty years have taken this form - such as Italo Calvino's

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p em span
content: Invisible Cities

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: , Robert Bly has also done three or four books of prose poems; they're small sequences because Bly is always a miniaturist, but all explore that capacity for growth through accretion. In Australia, Andrew Taylor's

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p em span
content: Parabolas

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: was a pivotal work, the first book-length collection of prose poems here. To mention just a couple of other Australian writers: Anna Couani attempts a form closer to the non-narrative short-story but with all the lyricism of an eternally displaced present-tense I mentioned before. Robert Kenny in

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p em span
content: Etcetera

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: tries to recreate and explore his childhood in the early 1950s: he uses short prose forms that list just a few non-essential items suddenly isolated to give that strange intensity like an unexpected photograph of a familiar scene. The book itself might not 'live' more than a few years, but its importance is greater than can be objectively measured: it's already given rise to other collections of a similar sort ?? by Laurie Duggan and Denis Gallagher, for instance.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: M:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p em span
content: Among the titles you mention

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: Parabolas

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p em span
content: and your own

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: Turning Full Circle

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p em span
content: both use the image of the curve, of the momentum that comes back to itself. Presumably recurrence is important in those sequences of prose poems you're talking about?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: TS: Yes, that hits very much to the centre. Finding what's within the circle. The greatest of all French prose poets must be Francis Ponge and his

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p em span
content: Soap

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: is a great circular pattern of finding and refinding...I hadn't previously traced that as an overriding formal focus, though I'd been intrigued by the capacity of the prose poem to work through extended groupings - and certainly the 'rondo' or 'variation' musical forms had seemed somehow parallel.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: M:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p em span
content: Yet in your own

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: Turning Full Circle

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p em span
content: you do use the image of music from time to time so you have that sense of development of motif, its recurrence and variation.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: TS: In my collection there were certain recurring motifs and a self-conscious preoccupation with 'turning full circle', of ending up where you started - but you never come back to where you started with exactly the same perspective.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: M:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p em span
content: Yes, there's no sense of any contrived connections and yet they obviously do relate to one another.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: TS: One has preoccupations in any time of one's life. But others which are much more basic come through. For the very last group I looked back - and then I tried to do different things, partly because I felt I'd been following a certain thread, seeing where it led, and suddenly I thought: no, there are other things that can be done too in this form. That was where I introduced the short-loin chops - to create a compressed short-story resonance. I used a third person there as a contrast. The temptation was to bust the form open, try something wider...

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: Reading that interview again, these decades later, I am of course struck with the extended book-length prose poem sequence that have been achieved in Australia in more recent years. Certainly Laurie Duggan's

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: The Ash Range

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: stands out, but also John Tranter's recent

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: Different Hands

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: (Folio/Fremantle Arts Centre Press 1998), which calls itself 'seven stories', comes more truly into the genre of prose poem (and, for that matter, some of David Brooks' stories similarly lean in that direction rather than as straightforward 'prose'). I myself have always considered my novel

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: White Stag of Exile

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: more truly a prose poem. The thing is, I must maintain, we now have an achieved body of work in this form. We should know more about it. Knowing it more closely, we can teach it more ably. That is my belief.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: Tom Shapcott

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: Professor of Creative Writing, University of Adelaide

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p strong em span
content: from Moya Costello

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote span
content: To the Editors,

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: Re Kevin Brophy's paper 'The Prose Poem: A Short History, a Brief Reflection and a Dose of the Real Thing' in the April 2002 edition of Text:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p a span
content: brophy.htm

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: , I quote from the paper:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: While the subversive French poetic form of vers libre was taken up by English writers in the modernist era to the point where free verse now dominates poetry written in English,

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p strong span
content: there has been no comparable interest in the prose poem among English-speaking writers.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: [my emphasis]

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: For the Soundings '97 poetry conference in Adelaide, I delivered a paper on the prose poem (unpublished, though similar comments in it appear in my articles 'The Fetishized Fragment'? Nah! 'Flow sucks'!

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: Redout

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: 28 1999 and 'An Effort of Non-compliance' online in

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: M/C Reviews

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: at

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p a span
content: ~ausstud/mc/reviews/features/women/effort.html

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: ). The conference paper was entitled 'the prose poem says find me'. It's a quote from joanne burns' manifesto in that now classic text

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: Poetry and Gender from Brooks and Walker

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: (UQP 1989). burns talks of herself as 'a hybrid, prose poetie sort of poet'. In the same book Pamela Brown says of her prose pieces that they are 'snapshots of conditions. Incidents of emotion. Episodes from a long running serial. Chronicles of a transition which is never completed'.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: The best exemplary practitioners of the prose poem to be found anywhere at any time are among contemporary Australian women writers (often categorised as feminist/experimental), including burns and Brown. Anna Couani and Susan Hampton are two more.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: Brophy comments in his paper:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: One consequence of the relative neglect of the prose poem in English is its lasting presence as a subversive and alternative poetic tradition: a permanent shadow thrown by the dominance of free verse; a niggling outsider; an exotic and possibly decadent third way somewhere between prose and poetry.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: All of the women I mention above have been working in the form since at least the early 1980s. All of them at one stage belonged to the Sydney Women Writers' Workshop, a workshop characterised as feminist and experimental, and one of its aims for being set up was to counter patriarchal practices in writing and publishing. The four women mentioned have, between them, have published over 20 books.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: Hampton's first book Costumes (1981) contained some prose poems gems such as 'The Kitchen of Aunty Mi and Aunty Pearl', and her latest fantastic book,

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: A Latin Primer

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: (Cerberus 1998), could be said to contain one long extended (brilliant) prose poem.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: Brophy asks and answers his question:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: What does it feel like then to be writing a prose poem?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: In her statement in

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: Poetry and Gender

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: burns says:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote blockquote p span
content: the prose poem, the poem in the prose is more humble, or perhaps more patient, more subtle. it knows the potential, the freedom of not being too obvious. the prose poem says find me.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: Anna Gibbs noted in her paper on feminism and fictocriticism (Text October 1997):

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p a span
content: gibbs.htm

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: , that the prose poem is one of the 'indeterminate forms' of 'literary detritus' that fictocriticism makes use of. (Heather Kerr and Amanda Nettelbeck edited

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: The Space Between: Australian Women Writing Fictocriticism

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: (UWA 1998), and Gail Jones work in T

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: he House of Breathing

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: (FACP 19992) and

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: Fetish Live

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: s (FACP 1997) is regarded as fictoctiticial. These might be places to look further for Australian women writing the prose poem.)

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: I was very concerned to have my collection of short prose pieces

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p em span
content: Small Ecstasies

tag: html body text table tbody tr td blockquote p span
content: (UQP 1994) not described as a collection of short stories, because it contains a variety of short prose forms, including the prose poem.
